instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used to discriminate sunflower seeds?
Output: The related study used visible spectrum to discriminate sunflower seeds.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to discriminate sunflower seeds?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used to discriminate sunflower seeds were multi-spectral imaging data extraction using a multi-spectral radiometer (MSR5) and considering five features in red (R), blue (B), green (G), spectral bands shortwave infrared (SWIR), and near infrared (NIR) ranging from 450 nm to 1550 nm.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the classifiers to discriminate sunflower seeds and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the classifiers in discriminating sunflower seeds was accuracy. The accuracy results ranged from 92.70% to 98.2% depending on the size of the region of interest.

instruction: How were the machine learning models utilized in the related study to discriminate sunflower seeds based on spectral and textural features?
Output: In the related study, four supervised machine learning models were utilized to discriminate sunflower seeds based on spectral and textural features. The models used were deep learning J4, support vector machine, random committee, and Bayes net. These models were employed to optimize the multi-feature dataset obtained from the preprocessing stage. The dataset consisted of 53 multi-features extracted from each region of the sunflower seeds. Additionally, the chi-square feature selection technique was applied to select 11 optimized fused multi-features. The accuracies achieved by the models were 98.2% for deep learning J4, 97.5% for support vector machine, 96.6% for random committee, and 94.8% for Bayes net.

instruction: How does the accuracy of the four supervised classifiers compare to traditional methods in discriminating sunflower seeds based on spectral and textural features?
Output: The accuracy of the four supervised classifiers in discriminating sunflower seeds based on spectral and textural features is very promising, with accuracies ranging from 94.8% to 98.2%.
